title: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court
overview: Capitalize the titles of judges and officials when used before a name ('Chief Justice Marshall') or when referring to a specific person ('the President'). Do not capitalize when used generically ('any justice may...'). Terms of court (like 'Fall Term') are capitalized when naming a specific term of a specific court. Always capitalize 'Court' when naming the U.S. Supreme Court or when the reference is to the court in a case name in text ('the Court held...'). Otherwise, lowercase 'court'.

before_names.rule: CAPITALIZE when used before a name

specific_person_reference.rule: CAPITALIZE when referring to a specific person

generic_usage.rule: DO NOT CAPITALIZE when used generically

specific_terms.rule: CAPITALIZE when naming a specific term of a specific court

generic_terms.rule: DO NOT CAPITALIZE when used generically

u_s_supreme_court.rule: ALWAYS CAPITALIZE 'Court' when naming the U.S. Supreme Court

court_in_case_name.rule: CAPITALIZE 'Court' when reference is to the court in a case name in text
examples: In Smith v. Jones, the Court held that...

9.1.title: Textual References to Professors
9.1.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
9.1.rule: In text (as opposed to in citations), omit 'Professor' in front of names.

examples.description: If an author has 'Professor' in front of the name in the text, leave it as is

9.2.title: Textual References to Judges as Authors of Judicial Materials
9.2.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
9.2.rule: In text, if a judge is the author of a judicial opinion or other document being discussed, use 'Justice' or 'Judge' (etc.) before their name.

9.3.title: Judges as Authors in General
9.3.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
9.3.rule: In text, if a judge is NOT the author of the document being discussed, use just the judge's last name without a title.

examples.wrong: Justice Sotomayor joined the majority opinion...

judges_as_authors.rule: Use title (Justice/Judge) + last name when judge authored the document

judges_not_as_authors.rule: Use only last name, NO title, when judge is not the author

citations.rule: In citations, use proper abbreviations from Table T11

important: Always capitalize 'Court' when referring to the U.S. Supreme Court specifically
The difference between author and non-author references is critical for proper judge citation
Generic references to judges/officials should NOT be capitalized
Terms of court are capitalized only when referring to a specific term (e.g., 'Fall Term 2023')
The context determines capitalization - before a name vs. generic reference
quick_reference: Before a name = CAPITALIZE (Chief Justice Marshall)
Generic = lowercase (any justice, a federal judge)
Judge authored document = Use title (Justice Sotomayor's opinion)
Judge did not author = No title (Sotomayor joined)

source: Bluebook 21st Edition - Rule 9: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court
